title: Getting Started
content:
Getting Started # When you first sign up to a company, you’ll need to create an account. After you’ve created an account, you’ll be offered a choice:
To create a company To join a company Creating a company # When creating a company, the name must be unique. Also, you can only be attached one to company at a time. If you wish to leave a company, please contact us.
Joining a company # If you’ve been given a link, please follow it. If you don’t already have an account, you will be asked to create one. You will then be added to the company, and have access to the subscribed products.
Adding a new user to your company # To add a user to your company and give them access to the subscribed products, you can follow these steps:
Login to dev-team-tools Head to the settings page Scroll down to the Invite User section Input the email address of the new user Set the level of the user Admin, if you’d like them to have elevated permissions to perform actions within the system User, as someone who can use the system and make smaller changes e.g. creating / updating feature switches Copy the link and give it to the person you’d like to add

title: Environments
content:
Environments # Creating # Before you can use some products in the system, you will need to create an environment. An environment in dev-team-tools should map 1:1 to your defined environments within your system, e.g. stage to stage, and prod to prod. So for each environment you have, there should be a corrisponding dev-team-tool’s environment defined.
These must have a unique name within your system, and will be used with the SDK / rest requests so we recommend making them human readable.
Setting a default # On top of this, you can define a default environment, which is the one you’ll load into automatically when navigating to a product. For example if you have defined a stage environment and set it to default, this will be the environment that loads when you initially view your feature switches.
Colours # Setting a colour has no real effect on the system, except making it easier to tell which environment you’re currently acting within. It’s recomended you pick different colours for each environment.
Managing # You can manage your environments at any time.
You can:
edit the colour set if it’s the default environment Deleting an evironment # Sometimes, you might wish to delete an environment. Doing so will remove all of the assoicated items with it, like feature switches.
